tn.text: In defending his apostleship from God, Paul continues to state specific things that have happened to him since he became a believer.
"I will continue talking, but now about"

tn.ref: visions and revelations from the Lord
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Paul uses the words "visions" and "revelations" to mean the same thing in hendiadys for emphasis. AT: "things that the Lord has allowed only me to see" or 2) Paul is speaking of two different things. AT: "secret things that the Lord has let me see with my eyes and other secrets that he has told me about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])

tn.ref: I know a man in Christ
tn.text: Paul is actually speaking of himself as if he were speaking of someone else, but this should be translated literally if possible.

tn.ref: whether in the body or out of the body, I do not know
tn.text: Paul continues to describe himself as if this happened to another person. "I do not know if this man was in his physical body or in his spiritual body"
"only God knows"
This refers to the dwelling place of God rather than the sky or outer space (the planets, stars, and the universe).
Paul continues to speak of himself as though he were speaking of someone else.

tn.ref: this man ... was caught up into paradise
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: Possible meanings are 1) "God took this man ... into paradise" or 2) "an angel took this man ... into paradise." If possible, it would be best not to name the one who took the man: "someone took ... paradise" or "they took ... paradise."
suddenly and forcefully held and taken
Possible meanings are 1) heaven or 2) the third heaven or 3) a special place in heaven.
"of that person"

tn.ref: I will not boast, except about my weaknesses
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "I will boast only of my weaknesses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
As Paul defends his apostleship from God, he tells of the weakness that God gave him to keep him humble.
When Paul speaks of his "thorn in the flesh," he reveals that he is the "man" he spoke of in [[:en:bible:notes:2co:12:01|12:2-5]].

tn.ref: heard from me. I will also keep from boasting because of the extraordinary kind of those revelations. Therefore, so I would not be puffed up with pride, a thorn
tn.text: Another possible meaning is "heard from me. Therefore, so I would not be puffed up with pride because of the extraordinary kind of those revelations, a thorn."

tn.ref: will think more of me than what is seen
tn.text: "gives me more credit than what is seen"

tn.ref: because of the extraordinary kind of those revelations
tn.text: "because those revelations were so different from anything anyone else had ever seen"

tn.ref: Therefore, so I would not be puffed up with pride
tn.text: "To keep me from being full of pride"
filled with air and so larger than is normal
Here Paul's physical problems are compared to a "thorn" piercing his "flesh." AT: affliction" or "a physical problem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"servant of Satan"
"to torment me"
Paul put these words at the beginning of the sentence to emphasize that he had prayed many times about his "thorn" ([[:en:bible:notes:2co:12:06|12:7]]).
"Lord about this thorn in the flesh," or "Lord about this affliction"

tn.ref: My grace is enough for you
tn.text: "I will be kind to you, and that is all you need"

tn.ref: for power is made perfect in weakness
tn.text: "for my power works best when you are weak"

tn.ref: the power of Christ might reside on me
tn.text: Paul speaks of Christ's power as if it were a tent built over him. Possible meanings are 1) "people might see that I have the power of Christ" or 2) "I might truly have the power of Christ." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I am content for Christ's sake in weaknesses, in insults, in troubles, in persecutions and distressing situations
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "I am content in weakness, insults, troubles, persecutions, and distressing situations if these things come because I belong to Christ" or 2) "I am content in weakness ... if these things cause more people to know Christ."
"when I am weak"
"when people try to make me angry by saying that I am a bad person"
"when I am suffering"
"when there is trouble"

tn.ref: For whenever I am weak, then I am strong
tn.text: Paul is saying that when he is no longer strong enough to do what needs to be done, Christ, who is more powerful than Paul could ever be, will work through Paul to do what needs to be done. However, it would be best to translate these words literally, if your language allows.
Paul reminds the believers in Corinth of the true signs of an apostle and of his humility before them to strengthen them.
"I am acting like a fool"
"You forced me to talk this way"

tn.ref: I should have been praised by you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "it is praise that you should have given me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Possible meanings are 1) "praise" ([[:en:bible:notes:2co:03:01|03:1]]) or 2) "recommend" ([[:en:bible:notes:2co:04:01|04:2]]).

tn.ref: For I was not at all inferior to
tn.text: By using the negative form, Paul is saying strongly that those Corinthians who think that he is inferior are wrong. AT: "For I am just as good as" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

apostles** - Paul uses irony here to show that they are less important then they claim to be. AT: "those teachers whom some think are better than anyone else." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:2co:11:05|11:05]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: The true signs of an apostle were performed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form, with emphasis on the "signs." AT: "It is the true signs of an apostle that I performed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Use the same word both times.

tn.ref: signs and wonders and mighty deeds
tn.text: These are the "true signs of an apostle" that Paul performed "with complete patience."

tn.ref: how were you less important than the rest of the churches, except that ... you?
tn.text: Paul is emphasizing that the Corinthians are wrong to accuse him of wanting to do them harm. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "I treated you the same way I treated all the other churches, except that ... you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I was not a burden to you
tn.text: "I did not ask you for money or other things I needed"

Paul is being ironic to shame the Corinthians. Both he and they know that he has done them no wrong, but they have been treating him as though he has wronged them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
not asking them for money and other things he needed
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "What I want is that you love and accept me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: children should not save up for the parents
tn.text: Young children are not responsible for saving money or other goods to give to their healthy parents.

tn.ref: I will most gladly spend and be spent
tn.text: Paul speaks of his work and his physical life as if it were money that he or God could spend. AT: "I will gladly do any work and gladly allow God to permit people to kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "souls" is a metonym for the people themselves. AT: "for you" or "so you will live well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: If I love you more, am I to be loved less?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "If I love you so much, you should not love me so little." or "If ... much, you should love me more than you do." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
It is not clear what it is that Paul's love is "more" than. It is probably best to use "very much" or a "so much" that can be compared to "so little" later in the sentence.

tn.ref: But, since I am so crafty, I am the one who caught you by deceit
tn.text: Paul uses irony to shame the Corinthians who think he lied to them even if he did not ask them for money. AT: "but others think I was deceptive and used trickery" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: Did I take advantage of you by anyone I sent to you?
tn.text: Both Paul and the Corinthians know the answer is no. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "No one that I sent to you has taken advantage of you!" (See ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Did Titus take advantage of you?
tn.text: Both Paul and the Corinthians know the answer is no. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Titus did not take advantage of you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Did we not walk in the same way?
tn.text: Paul speaks of living as if it were walking on a road. Both Paul and the Corinthians know the answer to the question is yes. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "We all have the same attitude and live alike." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Did we not walk in the same steps?
tn.text: Paul speaks of living as if it were walking on a road. Both Paul and the Corinthians know the answer to the question is yes. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "We all do things the same way." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Do you think all of this time we have been defending ourselves to you?
tn.text: Paul is asking a rhetorical question, AT: "It is wrong for you to think that all of this time we have been defending ourselves to you." Some translate this as a statement. AT: "You have been thinking all this time that we have been defending ourselves to you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Paul speaks of God knowing everything Paul does as if God were physically present and observed everything Paul said and did. AT: "Before God" or "With God as witness" or "In the presence of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"to strengthen you." Paul speaks of knowing how to obey God and desiring to obey him as if it were physical growth. AT: "so that you would know God and obey him better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I may not find you as I wish
tn.text: "I may not like what I find" or "I may not like what I see you doing"

tn.ref: you might not find me as you wish
tn.text: "you might not like what you see in me"

tn.ref: there may be arguments, jealousy, outbursts of anger, selfish ambition, gossip, pride, and disorder
tn.text: The abstract nouns arguments, jealousy, outbursts of anger, selfish ambition, gossip, pride, and disorder" can be translated using verbs. Possible meanings are 1) "some of you will be arguing with us, jealous of us, suddenly becoming very angry with us, talking about our private lives, being proud, and opposing us as we try to lead you" or 2) "some of you will be arguing with each other, jealous of each other, suddenly becoming very angry with each other, talking about each other's private lives, being proud, and opposing those whom God has chosen to lead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: I might be grieved by many of those who have sinned before now
tn.text: "I will be grieved because many of them have not given up their old sins"

tn.ref: did not repent of the impurity and sexual immorality and lustful indulgence
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Paul is saying almost the same thing three times for emphasis. AT: "did not stop commiting the sexual sins that they practiced" or 2) Paul is speaking of three different sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

The abstract noun impurity can be translated using a modified noun phrase. AT: "of secretly thinking about and desiring things that do not please God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The abstract noun "immorality" can be translated using a modified noun phrase. AT: "of doing sexually immoral deeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The abstract noun "indulgence" can be translated using a verb phrase. AT: "of ... doing things that satisfy immoral sexual desire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
